## GAD-7 vs TFEQ

GAD-7 vs TFEQ Are you a psychologist or social scientist struggling to harmonise questionnaire items such as those found in the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Three Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ)? A common challenge faced in longitudinal studies is comparing and matching distinct questionnaires to draw insightful conclusions. This is where Harmony, a revolutionary software dedicated to harmonisation, comes into play. With Harmony, the tedious task of "GAD-7 vs TFEQ" comparison gets significantly simplified. Harnessing the power of natural language processing and generative AI models, Harmony eases the process of matching items between the GAD-7 and TFEQ (or any other instruments you need compared). All you need to do is select the instruments from the provided database or directly upload your own instruments in PDF form. Through its advanced algorithms, the software provides percentage match between each item in your chosen questionnaires, in this case, "GAD-7 vs TFEQ". Furthermore, Harmony relieves you of the constraints imposed by language barriers. The software has the capability to compare items across multiple languages effortlessly. So, whether you're investigating relationships between eating habits, anxiety, and other social conditions, or checking the consistency of results across studies, Harmony can be your trusted ally for "GAD-7 vs TFEQ" comparisons and beyond. Don't compromise the potential of your research â€“ give Harmony a go today.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
